pages.sentence: I am at the counting platform. I see the number line on the wall. The numbers go from zero to twenty.
pages.mathConcept: Number lines show counting order
pages.mathTip: Numbers go in order. Each number is one more than the last.

pages.sentence: I start at five. I count up. Five, six, seven. I moved up by one each time.
pages.mathConcept: Counting up means adding one
pages.mathTip: When you count up, you add one.

pages.question: I start at 7. I count up two numbers. Where do I land?
pages.mathContext: I am counting on the number line.
pages.mathHint: Start at seven. Count up one, then up one more.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Counting up is adding.

pages.sentence: I stand at ten. I count down. Ten, nine, eight. I moved down by one each time.
pages.mathConcept: Counting down means subtracting one
pages.mathTip: When you count down, you subtract one.

pages.question: I start at 12. I count down two numbers. Where do I land?
pages.mathContext: I am counting backward on the number line.
pages.mathHint: Start at twelve. Count down one, then down one more.
pages.successMessage: Great! Counting down is subtracting.

pages.menuStory: The snack stand has treats. I choose one.

pages.sentence: I count the people waiting. I start at six. One more person comes. Now there are seven people.
pages.mathConcept: Adding one is the same as counting up one
pages.mathTip: Six plus one equals seven. That is counting up.

pages.question: How many tickets do I have now?
pages.mathContext: I have eight tickets. I get one more.
pages.mathHint: Count up from eight. What number comes next?
pages.successMessage: Yes! Eight plus one is nine. You counted up.

pages.sentence: I have nine coins. I spend one coin. Now I have eight coins left.
pages.mathConcept: Subtracting one is the same as counting down one
pages.mathTip: Nine minus one equals eight. That is counting down.

pages.question: How many napkins are left?
pages.mathContext: I have eleven napkins. I use one napkin.
pages.mathHint: Count down from eleven. What number comes before?
pages.successMessage: Nice! Eleven minus one is ten. You counted down.

pages.question: Where do I land?
pages.mathContext: I start at five. I count up two times.
pages.mathHint: Start at five. Count up: six, seven.
pages.successMessage: Great! You counted on from five.

pages.question: Where do I land?
pages.mathContext: I start at nine. I count back two times.
pages.mathHint: Start at nine. Count back: eight, seven.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! You counted back from nine.

previewConcepts.example: I have 3 apples. I get 2 more. Now I have 5.
Find the numbers. Find the action.
Use objects or fingers to count.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the fruit stand. I see baskets of fruit. The vendor smiles and says hello.
pages.mathConcept: Setting the scene for word problems
pages.mathTip: Word problems tell a story with numbers.

pages.sentence: I have three apples in my bag. I pick two more apples. Now I have five apples in my bag.
pages.mathConcept: Joining numbers together is addition
pages.mathTip: When you get more, you add.

pages.question: How many apples do I have now?
pages.mathContext: I have three apples in my bag. I pick two more apples.
pages.mathHint: Count all the apples. Start with three. Add two more.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Three plus two equals five.

pages.sentence: I see four oranges on the left shelf. I see three oranges on the right shelf. There are seven oranges in all.
pages.mathConcept: Putting groups together
pages.mathTip: Add to find how many in all.

pages.question: How many oranges are there in all?
pages.mathContext: There are six oranges on the left. There are five oranges on the right.
pages.mathHint: Add the two groups together.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Six plus five equals eleven.

pages.menuStory: The fruit looks fresh and colorful. I choose my favorite.

pages.question: How many pieces of fruit does she have now?
pages.mathContext: My sister has seven strawberries. I give her four more strawberries.
pages.mathHint: Start with seven. Count on four more.
pages.successMessage: Great work! Seven plus four equals eleven.

pages.sentence: The vendor puts eight pears in a basket. Then he adds five more pears to the basket. Now there are thirteen pears.
pages.mathConcept: Adding within 20
pages.mathTip: You can count on from the bigger number.

pages.question: How many fruits are in the box now?
pages.mathContext: There are nine apples in a box. The farmer adds six more apples.
pages.mathHint: Start at nine. Count on six more: ten, eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Nine plus six equals fifteen.

pages.question: How many total fruits do I buy?
pages.mathContext: I buy eight oranges and seven lemons.
pages.mathHint: Add eight and seven. You can make ten first: 8 + 2 = 10, then add 5 more.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Eight plus seven equals fifteen.

previewConcepts.example: I have 8 bowls. I use 3. I have 5 left.
Start with the total. Remove some.

previewConcepts.concept: Count back or count what remains
previewConcepts.example: You can count backward to subtract.

pages.sentence: I am at the noodle shop. I see steaming bowls on the counter. The cook is busy making more noodles.
pages.mathConcept: Setting up a subtraction story
pages.mathTip: Subtraction stories tell about things being taken away or used up.

pages.sentence: There are seven bowls of noodles. Three customers take bowls. Now there are four bowls left.
pages.mathConcept: Taking away is subtraction
pages.mathTip: When you take away, you subtract.

pages.question: How many bowls are left?
pages.mathContext: There are seven bowls of noodles. Three customers take bowls.
pages.mathHint: Start with seven. Take away three. Count what is left.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Seven minus three equals four.

pages.sentence: The cook has ten eggs. She uses four eggs to make noodles. She has six eggs left.
pages.mathConcept: Using objects is subtraction
pages.mathTip: When you use some, subtract to find what is left.

pages.question: How many chopsticks are left?
pages.mathContext: There are twelve chopsticks in the jar. I take out five chopsticks.
pages.mathHint: Start at twelve. Count back five.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Twelve minus five equals seven.

pages.menuStory: The menu has many choices. I pick my favorite kind of noodles.

pages.question: How many napkins are left in the holder?
pages.mathContext: There are fifteen napkins in the holder. Customers use eight napkins.
pages.mathHint: Start with fifteen. Take away eight. Count what remains.
pages.successMessage: Great! Fifteen minus eight equals seven.

pages.sentence: I see fourteen dumplings on the tray. My family eats six dumplings. There are eight dumplings left on the tray.
pages.mathConcept: Subtracting larger numbers within 20
pages.mathTip: You can count back or think about what is left.

pages.question: How many spring rolls are left?
pages.mathContext: The cook makes sixteen spring rolls. He sells nine spring rolls.
pages.mathHint: Start at sixteen. Count back nine, or think: nine plus what equals sixteen?
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Sixteen minus nine equals seven.

pages.question: How many customers are still waiting?
pages.mathContext: There are thirteen customers waiting. Seven customers get their food and leave.
pages.mathHint: Start with thirteen. Take away seven. You can count back.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Thirteen minus seven equals six.

previewConcepts.example: You can add in any order

pages.sentence: I walk into the bakery. I smell fresh bread and sweet pastries. The baker shows me three trays of treats.
pages.mathConcept: Setting up for adding three numbers
pages.mathTip: When you have three numbers, you add two first, then add the third.

pages.sentence: I see two croissants on the first tray. I see three croissants on the second tray. I see one croissant on the third tray. There are six croissants in all.
pages.mathConcept: Adding three numbers by grouping
pages.mathTip: Add the first two numbers. Then add the third number.

pages.question: How many croissants in all?
pages.mathContext: There are two croissants, then three croissants, then one croissant.
pages.mathHint: Add two and three first. That makes five. Then add one more.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Two plus three plus one equals six.

pages.sentence: The baker puts four cookies, two cookies, and four cookies in a bag. I can group the fours together. Four plus four equals eight. Then I add two more. The total is ten cookies.
pages.mathConcept: Grouping numbers that are easy to add
pages.mathTip: Look for doubles or easy pairs. Add those first.

pages.question: How many muffins did I buy?
pages.mathContext: I buy three muffins, five muffins, and three muffins.
pages.mathHint: Look for the doubles. Three plus three equals six. Then add five.
pages.successMessage: Great! You grouped the threes first. Three plus three plus five equals eleven.

pages.menuStory: The bakery has so many delicious treats. I choose one to eat now.

pages.sentence: I see seven rolls, three rolls, and two rolls. I notice that three and seven make ten. Then I add two more. There are twelve rolls in all.
pages.mathConcept: Making ten to add three numbers
pages.mathTip: Look for two numbers that make ten. That makes adding easier.

pages.question: How many bagels in all?
pages.mathContext: There are six bagels, four bagels, and three bagels.
pages.mathHint: Six plus four makes ten. Then add three more.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! You made ten first. Six plus four plus three equals thirteen.

pages.question: How many tarts did I count?
pages.mathContext: I count two tarts, eight tarts, and five tarts.
pages.mathHint: Two plus eight makes ten. Then add five more.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Two plus eight plus five equals fifteen.

pages.question: How many pies on the shelf?
pages.mathContext: The baker arranges five pies, three pies, and five pies on the shelf.
pages.mathHint: Look for doubles. Five plus five equals ten. Then add three.
pages.successMessage: Wonderful! Five plus three plus five equals thirteen.

pages.sentence: I visit the bubble tea shop. The cashier shows me three cups and four cups. She says there are seven cups in all. Then she switches them. Four cups and three cups still make seven cups.
pages.mathConcept: Commutative property of addition
pages.mathTip: You can add numbers in any order. The sum stays the same.

pages.question: If 5 + 2 = 7, what is 2 + 5?
pages.mathContext: I learn about turn-around facts.
pages.mathHint: Turn-around facts have the same answer. The order does not matter.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Five plus two and two plus five both equal seven.

pages.sentence: The worker puts six tapioca pearls in one cup and four pearls in another cup. That makes ten pearls. She tells me this is a fact family. Six plus four equals ten. Four plus six equals ten. Ten minus six equals four. Ten minus four equals six.
pages.mathConcept: Fact families show related facts
pages.mathTip: A fact family uses the same three numbers to make four facts.

pages.question: Which fact belongs in the same family as 3 + 5 = 8?
pages.mathContext: I am learning fact families with three, five, and eight.
pages.mathHint: Fact families use the same three numbers. Look for three, five, and eight.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Three, five, and eight make a fact family.

pages.menuStory: The menu has many flavors. I pick my favorite bubble tea to drink.

pages.sentence: I use the numbers seven, two, and nine to write facts. Seven plus two equals nine. Two plus seven equals nine. Nine minus seven equals two. Nine minus two equals seven.
pages.mathConcept: Writing all four facts in a family
pages.mathTip: Start with addition facts. Then write subtraction facts using the same numbers.

pages.question: I know 4 + 5 = 9. What is 9 - 4?
pages.mathContext: I use the fact family for four, five, and nine.
pages.mathHint: If four plus five equals nine, then nine minus four equals five.
pages.successMessage: Great! You used the fact family.

pages.question: I know 7 + 6 = 13. What is 13 - 7?
pages.mathContext: I use addition to help with subtraction.
pages.mathHint: Seven plus six equals thirteen. So thirteen minus seven equals six.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! You used addition to solve subtraction.

pages.question: What number completes this fact family: 8 + ___ = 14, 14 - 8 = ___?
pages.mathContext: I am finding the missing number in a fact family.
pages.mathHint: What number do you add to eight to get fourteen? That same number is the answer to fourteen minus eight.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Eight plus six equals fourteen, and fourteen minus eight equals six.

pages.question: If 9 + 5 = 14, what is 5 + 9?
pages.mathContext: I check if turn-around facts work with bigger numbers.
pages.mathHint: You can add in any order. The sum is the same.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Nine plus five and five plus nine both equal fourteen.

previewConcepts.example: Make ten, use doubles, count on
The more you practice, the faster you get

pages.sentence: I arrive at the dumpling restaurant. The cook is making dumplings very fast. She knows her numbers quickly. I will practice my addition facts to get fast too.
pages.mathConcept: Building fluency with addition facts
pages.mathTip: Practice helps you get faster and more accurate.

pages.question: How many dumplings in all?
pages.mathContext: I count dumplings. Six plus six is a double.
pages.mathHint: Six plus six is a double. What is double six?
pages.successMessage: Yes! Six plus six equals twelve.

pages.question: How many dumplings now?
pages.mathContext: There are nine dumplings. I add one more.
pages.mathHint: Nine plus one is just counting up one from nine.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Nine plus one equals ten.

pages.question: How many dumplings in the groups?
pages.mathContext: I group seven dumplings and three dumplings.
pages.mathHint: Seven and three make ten.
pages.successMessage: Great! Seven plus three equals ten.

pages.menuStory: The restaurant has different kinds of dumplings. I choose my favorite.

pages.question: How many dumplings in all?
pages.mathContext: I add seven dumplings and eight dumplings.
pages.mathHint: Think of the double seven plus seven equals fourteen. Then add one more.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Seven plus eight equals fifteen.

pages.question: How many dumplings on the tray?
pages.mathContext: The cook puts five dumplings and seven dumplings on the tray.
pages.mathHint: You can make ten first. Five plus five equals ten. Then add two more.
pages.successMessage: Nice work! Five plus seven equals twelve.

pages.question: How many dumplings did I count?
pages.mathContext: I count nine dumplings and seven dumplings.
pages.mathHint: Nine plus one equals ten. Then add six more. Ten plus six equals sixteen.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Nine plus seven equals sixteen.

pages.question: How many dumplings in all?
pages.mathContext: There are eight steamed dumplings and six fried dumplings.
pages.mathHint: Eight plus two makes ten. Then add four more.
pages.successMessage: Wonderful! Eight plus six equals fourteen.

previewConcepts.concept: Count back or use fact families

pages.sentence: I am at the rice bowl shop. The server is very quick with numbers. She can subtract fast. I will practice my subtraction facts.
pages.mathConcept: Building fluency with subtraction facts
pages.mathTip: Knowing your subtraction facts helps you solve problems quickly.

pages.question: How many bowls are left?
pages.mathContext: There are ten bowls. One customer takes a bowl.
pages.mathHint: Ten minus one is just counting back one from ten.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Ten minus one equals nine.

pages.question: How many grains of rice are left?
pages.mathContext: I have ten grains of rice. I eat four grains.
pages.mathHint: Think: four plus what equals ten? Four plus six equals ten.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Ten minus four equals six.

pages.question: How many spoons are left?
pages.mathContext: There are eight spoons. Three spoons are used.
pages.mathHint: Count back three from eight: seven, six, five.
pages.successMessage: Great! Eight minus three equals five.

pages.menuStory: The menu has rice bowls with different toppings. I pick one.

pages.question: How many bowls are left?
pages.mathContext: The cook makes twelve bowls. Five bowls are sold.
pages.mathHint: Think: five plus what equals twelve? Five plus seven equals twelve.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Twelve minus five equals seven.

pages.question: How many chopsticks are left?
pages.mathContext: I see fifteen chopsticks. Seven are taken away.
pages.mathHint: Think: seven plus what equals fifteen? Seven plus eight equals fifteen.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Fifteen minus seven equals eight.

pages.question: How many napkins are left?
pages.mathContext: There are thirteen napkins. Eight napkins are used.
pages.mathHint: Think: eight plus what equals thirteen? Eight plus five equals thirteen.
pages.successMessage: Wonderful! Thirteen minus eight equals five.

pages.question: How many tables are empty?
pages.mathContext: The restaurant has seventeen tables. Nine tables are full.
pages.mathHint: Think: nine plus what equals seventeen? Nine plus eight equals seventeen.
pages.successMessage: Amazing! Seventeen minus nine equals eight.

previewConcepts.concept: Check if it is true or false

pages.sentence: I walk into the balance scale station. The worker shows me a scale. She says the equal sign is like a balance. Both sides must be the same.
pages.mathConcept: The equal sign means both sides are the same
pages.mathTip: Equal means the left side and right side have the same value.

pages.sentence: I see the equation three equals three. The worker says this is true. Three on the left and three on the right are the same.
pages.mathConcept: Understanding true equations
pages.mathTip: If both sides are equal, the equation is true.

pages.question: Is 5 = 5 true or false?
pages.mathContext: I check if both sides are equal.
pages.mathHint: Is five the same as five? Yes, so it is true.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Five equals five is true.

pages.sentence: I see another equation. Four plus one equals five. The worker puts four blocks and one block on the left. She puts five blocks on the right. The scale balances. It is true.
pages.mathConcept: Equations with operations can be true
pages.mathTip: Check both sides. If they are the same, it is true.

pages.question: Is 3 + 2 = 5 true or false?
pages.mathContext: I check if three plus two equals five.
pages.mathHint: Add three and two. Does it equal five? Yes, so it is true.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Three plus two equals five, so it is true.

pages.menuStory: The station has different balance activities. I choose one to try.

pages.sentence: I try an equation that is false. The worker shows me six equals seven. She says this is false. Six and seven are not the same. The scale does not balance.
pages.mathConcept: False equations do not balance
pages.mathTip: If both sides are different, the equation is false.

pages.question: Is 8 = 9 true or false?
pages.mathContext: I check if eight equals nine.
pages.mathHint: Are eight and nine the same? No, so it is false.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Eight does not equal nine, so it is false.

pages.question: Is 5 + 3 = 9 true or false?
pages.mathContext: I check if five plus three equals nine.
pages.mathHint: Add five and three. Does it equal nine? No, five plus three equals eight.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Five plus three equals eight, not nine. It is false.

pages.question: Is 4 + 3 = 2 + 5 true or false?
pages.mathContext: I check if both sides are equal. The left side is four plus three. The right side is two plus five.
pages.mathHint: Add both sides. Four plus three equals seven. Two plus five equals seven. Both sides are seven.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Both sides equal seven, so it is true.

pages.question: Is 10 - 4 = 6 true or false?
pages.mathContext: I check if ten minus four equals six.
pages.mathHint: Subtract four from ten. Does it equal six? Yes.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Ten minus four equals six, so it is true.

previewConcepts.concept: Use what you know to solve
previewConcepts.example: Think: what number makes it true?

pages.sentence: I enter the mystery number station. The detective shows me equations with missing numbers. She says I need to find what number goes in the blank to make it true.
pages.mathConcept: Finding unknown numbers in equations
pages.mathTip: The missing number makes the equation true.

pages.sentence: I see my first mystery. Three plus blank equals seven. I think: three plus what makes seven? Three plus four makes seven. The missing number is four.
pages.mathConcept: Missing addend in addition
pages.mathTip: Ask yourself: what do I add to get the answer?

pages.question: What number goes in the blank? 5 + ___ = 8
pages.mathContext: I need to find the missing number.
pages.mathHint: Five plus what equals eight? Think: five plus three equals eight.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Five plus three equals eight.

pages.sentence: The detective shows me a new mystery. Blank plus six equals ten. I think: what plus six makes ten? Four plus six makes ten. The missing number is four.
pages.mathConcept: Missing number at the beginning
pages.mathTip: It does not matter where the blank is. Think about what makes it true.

pages.question: What number goes in the blank? ___ + 4 = 9
pages.mathContext: The missing number is at the beginning.
pages.mathHint: What plus four equals nine? Think: five plus four equals nine.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Five plus four equals nine.

pages.menuStory: The detective has different mystery cases. I choose one to solve.

pages.sentence: Now I see a subtraction mystery. Twelve minus blank equals five. I think: twelve minus what makes five? Twelve minus seven makes five. The missing number is seven.
pages.mathConcept: Missing number in subtraction
pages.mathTip: For subtraction, think: what do I take away to get the answer?

pages.question: What number goes in the blank? 10 - ___ = 6
pages.mathContext: I need to find what number to subtract.
pages.mathHint: Ten minus what equals six? Think: ten minus four equals six.
pages.successMessage: Great! Ten minus four equals six.

pages.question: What number goes in the blank? 8 + ___ = 15
pages.mathContext: I find the missing addend with larger numbers.
pages.mathHint: Eight plus what equals fifteen? Count on from eight or think: eight plus seven equals fifteen.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Eight plus seven equals fifteen.

pages.question: What number goes in the blank? ___ - 5 = 9
pages.mathContext: The missing number is the starting number.
pages.mathHint: What number minus five equals nine? Think: nine plus five equals fourteen. So fourteen minus five equals nine.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! Fourteen minus five equals nine.

pages.question: What number goes in the blank? 13 - ___ = 6
pages.mathContext: I solve a harder subtraction mystery.
pages.mathHint: Thirteen minus what equals six? Think: six plus seven equals thirteen. So thirteen minus seven equals six.
pages.successMessage: Amazing! Thirteen minus seven equals six.

pages.sentence: I am at the train number station. I see train numbers on the platform. The trains have big numbers from 1 to 120.
pages.mathConcept: We can count all the way to 120.
pages.mathTip: Numbers go in order. Each number is one more than the last.

pages.question: What number comes after 19?
pages.mathContext: I count the trains. I see train 19. What is the next train number?
pages.mathHint: Count up. After 19 comes the next number.
pages.successMessage: Yes! After 19 comes 20. You counted up!

pages.sentence: I count past 99. After 99 comes 100. One hundred! Then 101, 102, 103. The numbers keep going.
pages.mathConcept: After 99 comes 100. Then we count 101, 102, 103.
pages.mathTip: 100 is a big number. It is 10 tens. After 100, we keep counting.

pages.question: What number comes after 99?
pages.mathContext: I see train 99 pull into the station. The next train arrives. What number is it?
pages.mathHint: After 99, we reach one hundred. That is 100.
pages.successMessage: Great! After 99 comes 100. That is one hundred!

pages.sentence: I practice counting. 108, 109, 110. I read each number out loud. One hundred eight. One hundred nine. One hundred ten.
pages.mathConcept: We can read numbers over 100.
pages.mathTip: Say the hundreds part first. Then the tens and ones.

pages.menuStory: The snack cart comes by. I am hungry. I pick a snack to eat on my train ride.

pages.question: What comes after 110?
pages.mathContext: I count the train cars. I count 110 cars. Then I count one more. What number?
pages.mathHint: Count up from 110. The next number is 111.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! After 110 comes 111. You are counting past 100!

pages.sentence: I count train 115, train 116, train 117. I am getting close to 120! The last train is train 120.
pages.mathConcept: 120 is a big number. We can count all the way there.
pages.mathTip: Practice counting. Say the numbers in order.

pages.question: What number is missing? 117, ___, 119
pages.mathContext: One train number is covered with steam. I see 117 and 119. What number is in the middle?
pages.mathHint: Count from 117. What comes before 119?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 118 comes between 117 and 119!

pages.question: What number comes right before 120?
pages.mathContext: Train 120 is the last train. What train comes right before it?
pages.mathHint: Count back one from 120. What is one less than 120?
pages.successMessage: Great work! 119 comes right before 120!

pages.sentence: I am at the dumpling shop. Dumplings come in boxes of 10. I can count the boxes and the extra dumplings.
pages.mathConcept: Numbers have tens and ones.
pages.mathTip: A ten is a group of 10 ones.

pages.sentence: I have 10 dumplings. I put them in one box. 10 ones equal 1 ten! The box has 10 dumplings inside.
pages.mathConcept: 10 ones make 1 ten.
pages.mathTip: When you have 10 ones, you can trade them for 1 ten.

pages.question: How many ones make 1 ten?
pages.mathContext: The shop worker fills a box. How many dumplings go in the box to make 1 ten?
pages.mathHint: Think: 10 ones equal 1 ten.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 10 ones make 1 ten!

pages.sentence: I count my dumplings. I have 2 boxes and 3 extra dumplings. That is 2 tens and 3 ones. The number is 23.
pages.mathConcept: We write numbers using tens and ones.
pages.mathTip: The tens digit shows how many tens. The ones digit shows how many ones.

pages.question: I have 2 tens and 3 ones. What number is that?
pages.mathContext: I count 2 boxes of dumplings and 3 extra dumplings. What number do I have?
pages.mathHint: 2 tens and 3 ones make 23.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 2 tens and 3 ones is 23!

pages.menuStory: The shop has many flavors. I choose my favorite kind of dumplings.

pages.sentence: I see 35 dumplings. How many tens? How many ones? I count 3 tens and 5 ones. 35 has 3 tens and 5 ones.
pages.mathConcept: Every two-digit number has a tens digit and a ones digit.
pages.mathTip: The first digit shows tens. The second digit shows ones.

pages.question: How many tens are in 35?
pages.mathContext: I have 35 dumplings. I count the boxes of 10. How many tens?
pages.mathHint: Look at the tens digit. 35 has 3 tens.
pages.successMessage: Great! 35 has 3 tens!

pages.question: How many ones are in 35?
pages.mathContext: I have 35 dumplings. I count the extra dumplings not in a box. How many ones?
pages.mathHint: Look at the ones digit. 35 has 5 ones.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 35 has 5 ones!

pages.sentence: The worker bundles 10 dumplings into a new box. I watch the trade. 10 ones become 1 ten. That is how we make tens!
pages.mathConcept: We can trade 10 ones for 1 ten.
pages.mathTip: When you have 10 or more ones, make a new ten.

pages.question: I have 4 tens and 6 ones. What number?
pages.mathContext: I build a number with base-ten blocks. I use 4 tens rods and 6 ones cubes. What number did I make?
pages.mathHint: Put the tens digit first, then the ones digit. 4 tens and 6 ones is 46.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 4 tens and 6 ones make 46!

pages.sentence: I am at the boba tea shop. I count the boba pearls. Teen numbers are special. They all have 1 ten and some ones.
pages.mathTip: Every teen number has 1 ten. Then we add the extra ones.

pages.sentence: I count 13 boba pearls. 13 is 1 ten and 3 ones. I fill one ten frame. Then I have 3 more pearls.
pages.mathConcept: 13 equals 10 plus 3.
pages.mathTip: Teen numbers are 10 and some more ones.

pages.question: 13 is the same as 10 plus what?
pages.mathContext: I have 13 boba pearls. I know 10 fill one cup. How many extra pearls do I have?
pages.mathHint: 13 is 10 plus 3. Think: 1 ten and 3 ones.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 13 is 10 plus 3!

pages.sentence: I make 15. I put 10 pearls in a cup. Then I add 5 more pearls. 15 is 1 ten and 5 ones. All teen numbers work this way!
pages.mathConcept: 15 equals 10 plus 5.
pages.mathTip: Find the ten first. Then add the extra ones.

pages.question: How many tens are in 15?
pages.mathContext: I count 15 boba pearls. How many groups of 10 do I have?
pages.mathHint: All teen numbers have 1 ten.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 15 has 1 ten!

pages.menuStory: The boba shop has yummy drinks. I pick my favorite flavor to drink.

pages.sentence: I practice teen numbers. 11 is 10 and 1. 12 is 10 and 2. 17 is 10 and 7. 19 is 10 and 9. They all have 1 ten!
pages.mathConcept: All numbers from 11 to 19 have 1 ten and some ones.
pages.mathTip: Teen numbers always start with 1 ten.

pages.question: 17 is 10 plus what number?
pages.mathContext: I have 17 pearls. I fill one cup with 10. How many pearls are left?
pages.mathHint: 17 is 1 ten and 7 ones. So 17 = 10 + 7.
pages.successMessage: Great! 17 is 10 plus 7!

pages.question: What number is 1 ten and 4 ones?
pages.mathContext: I build a number. I use 1 ten rod and 4 ones cubes. What number is it?
pages.mathHint: 1 ten and 4 ones make 14.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 1 ten and 4 ones is 14!

pages.sentence: The biggest teen number is 19. 19 is 1 ten and 9 ones. After 19 comes 20. 20 has 2 tens and 0 ones!
pages.mathConcept: 19 is the last teen number. Then comes 20.
pages.mathTip: After the teens, we get numbers with 2 tens, 3 tens, and more.

pages.question: I have 1 ten and 9 ones. What number?
pages.mathContext: I count my boba pearls. I have 1 full cup of 10 and 9 extra pearls. What number is that?
pages.mathHint: 1 ten and 9 ones is 19.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 1 ten and 9 ones is 19!

pages.sentence: I am at the egg tart tower. The tarts come in trays of 10. I can count by tens. 10, 20, 30!
pages.mathConcept: We can skip count by tens.
pages.mathTip: Count by tens: 10, 20, 30, 40. Each time we add 10 more.

pages.sentence: I count the trays. 10, 20, 30, 40, 50. Five trays is 50 tarts! When I count by tens, I add 10 each time.
pages.mathConcept: Counting by tens means adding 10 each time.
pages.mathTip: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50. Notice: they all end in zero!

pages.question: Count by tens. What comes after 30?
pages.mathContext: I count the trays. 10, 20, 30, and then what?
pages.mathHint: Count by tens. After 30 comes 40.
pages.successMessage: Yes! When counting by tens, after 30 comes 40!

pages.sentence: All tens end in zero. 10 has a 0. 20 has a 0. 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90. They all end in 0! That is how we know they are tens.
pages.mathConcept: Numbers that are only tens end in 0.
pages.mathTip: When a number ends in 0, it has 0 ones. Only tens!

pages.question: How many ones are in 50?
pages.mathContext: I have 50 egg tarts in trays. All trays are full. How many extra tarts not in a tray?
pages.mathHint: 50 is 5 tens and 0 ones. So there are 0 ones.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 50 has 0 ones. It is all tens!

pages.menuStory: The bakery has fresh treats. I choose a yummy pastry to eat.

pages.sentence: I keep counting by tens. 60, 70, 80, 90, 100! I can count all the way to 100 by tens. That is 10 tens!
pages.mathConcept: 10 tens equal 100.
pages.mathTip: Count by tens to reach 100 quickly.

pages.question: Count by tens. What comes after 70?
pages.mathContext: I count the trays. 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, and then?
pages.mathHint: Keep counting by tens. After 70 comes 80.
pages.successMessage: Great! After 70 comes 80 when counting by tens!

pages.question: How many tens are in 70?
pages.mathContext: I have 70 egg tarts. They are all in trays of 10. How many trays?
pages.mathHint: 70 is 7 tens and 0 ones. Count the tens: 7.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 70 has 7 tens!

pages.sentence: Counting by tens is fast! I do not count one by one. I jump by tens. 10, 20, 30, 40. I can count many things quickly!
pages.mathConcept: Skip counting by tens is faster than counting by ones.
pages.mathTip: Use tens to count large groups quickly.

pages.question: What number is missing? 40, 50, ___, 70
pages.mathContext: One tray number is hidden. I see 40, 50, blank, 70. What is the missing number?
pages.mathHint: Count by tens. After 50 comes 60.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 60 comes between 50 and 70!

pages.sentence: I am at the noodle shop. Noodles come in different bowl sizes. I can compare the numbers to see which is greater.
pages.mathConcept: We can compare two numbers to see which is greater or less.
pages.mathTip: Greater means bigger. Less means smaller.

pages.sentence: I compare 35 and 42. I check the tens first. 35 has 3 tens. 42 has 4 tens. 4 tens is more than 3 tens. So 42 is greater than 35.
pages.mathConcept: To compare numbers, check the tens digit first.
pages.mathTip: The number with more tens is greater.

pages.question: Which number is greater, 27 or 54?
pages.mathContext: I see two noodle bowls. One has 27 noodles. One has 54 noodles. Which bowl has more?
pages.mathHint: Compare tens first. 27 has 2 tens. 54 has 5 tens. 5 tens is more.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 54 is greater than 27 because 5 tens is more than 2 tens!

pages.sentence: Sometimes the tens are the same. Then I check the ones. 43 and 47 both have 4 tens. But 47 has 7 ones and 43 has 3 ones. 7 ones is more than 3 ones. So 47 is greater.
pages.mathConcept: When tens are equal, compare the ones.
pages.mathTip: Same tens? Check which has more ones.

pages.question: Which is greater, 62 or 68?
pages.mathContext: Two bowls both have 6 tens. One has 2 ones, one has 8 ones. Which is greater?
pages.mathHint: The tens are the same. Check the ones. 8 ones is more than 2 ones.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 68 is greater than 62 because 8 ones is more than 2 ones!

pages.menuStory: The noodle shop has many kinds. I choose my favorite noodles to eat.

pages.sentence: I use the symbols to compare. The symbol for greater than is the greater than sign. The symbol for less than is the less than sign. 56 is greater than 34. 34 is less than 56.
pages.mathConcept: We use symbols to show comparisons: greater than, less than, equal to.
pages.mathTip: The greater than sign points to the smaller number. The less than sign points to the bigger number.

pages.question: Which number is less, 71 or 89?
pages.mathContext: I compare two numbers. Which one is smaller?
pages.mathHint: Less means smaller. 71 has 7 tens, 89 has 8 tens. 71 is less.
pages.successMessage: Great! 71 is less than 89!

pages.sentence: Sometimes two numbers are equal. 45 equals 45. They are the same! When numbers are equal, we use the equal sign.
pages.mathConcept: When two numbers are the same, they are equal.
pages.mathTip: Equal means exactly the same amount.

pages.question: Is 52 greater than, less than, or equal to 52?
pages.mathContext: I have two bowls. Each has 52 noodles. How do the numbers compare?
pages.mathHint: 52 and 52 are the same number. They are equal.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 52 equals 52. They are the same!

pages.question: Which is greater, 38 or 41?
pages.mathContext: I compare 38 and 41. Which number is bigger?
pages.mathHint: Check tens first. 38 has 3 tens, 41 has 4 tens. 41 is greater.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 41 is greater than 38!

pages.sentence: I am at the fruit stand. I buy apples and oranges. I can add the numbers together. I add ones first, then tens.
pages.mathConcept: To add two-digit numbers, add the ones first, then add the tens.
pages.mathTip: Line up the tens and ones. Add each place separately.

pages.sentence: I have 23 apples. I buy 5 more apples. How many apples do I have now? I add the ones. 3 plus 5 equals 8 ones. The tens stay 2 tens. 23 plus 5 equals 28.
pages.mathConcept: When adding, start with the ones place.
pages.mathTip: 23 + 5: Add ones 3 + 5 = 8. Keep the tens. Answer: 28.

pages.question: How many apples in all?
pages.mathContext: I have 23 apples. I add 5 more apples.
pages.mathHint: Add the ones. 3 + 5 = 8. The tens stay 2. So 23 + 5 = 28.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 23 + 5 = 28. You added the ones!

pages.sentence: Now I try adding tens and ones together. I have 34 fruits. I buy 21 more fruits. I add ones first. 4 plus 1 equals 5 ones. Then I add tens. 3 tens plus 2 tens equals 5 tens. 34 plus 21 equals 55.
pages.mathConcept: Add ones, then add tens.

pages.question: How many fruits in total?
pages.mathContext: I count 34 apples and 20 oranges.
pages.mathHint: Add tens: 30 + 20 = 50. Add ones: 4 + 0 = 4. Total: 54.

pages.menuStory: The fruit stand has fresh fruit. I choose my favorite kind to buy.

pages.sentence: I practice more addition. 52 plus 33. Ones: 2 plus 3 equals 5. Tens: 5 tens plus 3 tens equals 8 tens. 52 plus 33 equals 85!
pages.mathConcept: Always add ones first, then tens.
pages.mathTip: Use base-ten blocks to see the tens and ones clearly.

pages.question: How many fruits in all?
pages.mathContext: I have 52 fruits in one basket. I add 7 more fruits.
pages.mathHint: Add the ones: 2 + 7 = 9. The tens stay 5. So 52 + 7 = 59.

pages.question: How many fruits do I have?
pages.mathContext: I buy 40 apples and 26 oranges.

pages.sentence: Adding is easy when I follow the steps. Add ones. Add tens. Check my answer. I can add any two numbers this way!
pages.mathConcept: Use a strategy: add ones, then add tens.
pages.mathTip: Practice makes addition faster and easier!

pages.question: How many apples in total?
pages.mathContext: I count 14 red apples and 30 green apples.
pages.mathHint: Add tens: 10 + 30 = 40. Add ones: 4 + 0 = 4. Total: 44.

pages.sentence: I am at the steamed bun kitchen. Sometimes when I add, I get 10 or more ones. Then I need to make a new ten! This is called regrouping.
pages.mathConcept: When ones add up to 10 or more, we regroup and make a new ten.
pages.mathTip: Watch for when ones reach 10. Trade 10 ones for 1 ten.

pages.sentence: I have 27 buns. I add 8 more buns. First I add the ones. 7 plus 8 equals 15. That is 1 ten and 5 ones! I trade 10 ones for 1 new ten. Now I have 3 tens and 5 ones. 27 plus 8 equals 35.
pages.mathConcept: When ones equal 10 or more, regroup to make a new ten.
pages.mathTip: 7 + 8 = 15. That is 1 ten and 5 ones. Regroup!

pages.question: How many buns now?
pages.mathContext: I have 27 buns in baskets. I add 8 more buns.
pages.mathHint: Add ones: 7 + 8 = 15. That is 1 ten and 5 ones. Regroup! 2 tens + 1 ten = 3 tens. Answer: 35.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 27 + 8 = 35. You regrouped 15 ones into 1 ten and 5 ones!

pages.sentence: I try another one. 36 plus 17. Ones: 6 plus 7 equals 13. That is 1 ten and 3 ones. I regroup! Tens: 3 tens plus 1 ten plus the new ten equals 5 tens. 36 plus 17 equals 53.
pages.mathConcept: Add ones, regroup if needed, then add all the tens.
pages.mathTip: 6 + 7 = 13. Regroup to 1 ten and 3 ones. Then add tens: 3 + 1 + 1 = 5 tens.

pages.question: How many buns in total?
pages.mathContext: I make 36 buns in the morning. I add 8 more buns.
pages.mathHint: Add ones: 6 + 8 = 14. Regroup to 1 ten and 4 ones. Tens: 3 + 1 = 4. Answer: 44.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 36 + 8 = 44. You regrouped 14 ones into 1 ten and 4 ones!

pages.menuStory: The kitchen makes different buns. I choose my favorite filling.

pages.sentence: Regrouping happens when the ones add up to 10 or more. I always check. Do I have 10 or more ones? If yes, I make a new ten!
pages.mathConcept: Check if ones equal 10 or more. If yes, regroup.
pages.mathTip: When ones reach 10, trade for 1 ten. Then add the tens.

pages.question: How many buns in all?
pages.mathContext: I have 48 buns on one tray. I add 7 more buns.
pages.mathHint: Add ones: 8 + 7 = 15. Regroup to 1 ten and 5 ones. Tens: 4 + 1 = 5. Answer: 55.
pages.successMessage: Great job! 48 + 7 = 55.

pages.sentence: I practice more. 29 plus 15. Ones: 9 plus 5 equals 14. Regroup to 1 ten and 4 ones. Tens: 2 plus 1 plus 1 equals 4 tens. 29 plus 15 equals 44.
pages.mathConcept: Practice regrouping to build skill.
pages.mathTip: Follow the steps: add ones, regroup if needed, add tens.

pages.question: How many total?
pages.mathContext: The baker makes 29 buns in the first batch and 8 in the second.
pages.mathHint: Add ones: 9 + 8 = 17. Regroup to 1 ten and 7 ones. Tens: 2 + 1 = 3. Answer: 37.

pages.question: How many buns in total?
pages.mathContext: I count 57 pork buns and 8 veggie buns.
pages.mathHint: Add ones: 7 + 8 = 15. Regroup to 1 ten and 5 ones. Tens: 5 + 1 = 6. Answer: 65.
pages.successMessage: Awesome! 57 + 8 = 65.

pages.sentence: I am at the elevator. The buttons go up and down. I can go 10 floors up or 10 floors down. This helps me practice 10 more and 10 less.
pages.mathConcept: Adding 10 means going up 10. Subtracting 10 means going down 10.
pages.mathTip: When you add or subtract 10, only the tens digit changes.

pages.sentence: I am on floor 34. I press the up button. The elevator goes up 10 floors. 34 plus 10 equals 44. I am now on floor 44. The tens changed from 3 to 4. The ones stayed 4.
pages.mathConcept: 10 more than a number means add 1 to the tens digit.
pages.mathTip: To find 10 more, add 1 ten. The ones stay the same.

pages.question: What is 10 more than 34?
pages.mathContext: I am on floor 34. I go up 10 floors. What floor am I on now?
pages.mathHint: Add 1 to the tens digit. 34 becomes 44.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 10 more than 34 is 44!

pages.sentence: Now I press the down button. I am on floor 56. I go down 10 floors. 56 minus 10 equals 46. The tens changed from 5 to 4. The ones stayed 6.
pages.mathConcept: 10 less than a number means subtract 1 from the tens digit.
pages.mathTip: To find 10 less, subtract 1 ten. The ones stay the same.

pages.question: What is 10 less than 56?
pages.mathContext: I am on floor 56. I go down 10 floors. What floor am I on?
pages.mathHint: Subtract 1 from the tens digit. 56 becomes 46.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 10 less than 56 is 46!

pages.menuStory: The elevator plays music. I choose which song I want to hear.

pages.sentence: I can do this in my head! I do not need to write it down. I just think about the tens digit. 10 more than 72? The tens goes from 7 to 8. That is 82!
pages.mathConcept: We can find 10 more or 10 less mentally.
pages.mathTip: Mental math means doing math in your head. It is fast!

pages.question: What is 10 more than 72?
pages.mathContext: I am on floor 72. The elevator goes up 10 floors. What floor now?
pages.mathHint: Think: 7 tens becomes 8 tens. 72 + 10 = 82.
pages.successMessage: Great! 10 more than 72 is 82!

pages.question: What is 10 less than 83?
pages.mathContext: I start on floor 83. I go down 10 floors. Where am I?
pages.mathHint: Think: 8 tens becomes 7 tens. 83 - 10 = 73.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 10 less than 83 is 73!

pages.sentence: I ride the elevator all day. Up 10, down 10. The pattern is easy. Only the tens digit changes. The ones stay exactly the same every time!
pages.mathConcept: The ones digit never changes when adding or subtracting 10.
pages.mathTip: Look for the pattern. This makes mental math easier!

pages.question: What is 10 more than 91?
pages.mathContext: I am on floor 91. I press the up button to go up 10 floors. What floor?
pages.mathHint: 9 tens plus 1 ten equals 10 tens. That is 100! 91 + 10 = 101.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 10 more than 91 is 101. You went past 100!

pages.sentence: I am at the rice ball shop. Rice balls come in packs of 10. I can subtract tens to find how many are left.
pages.mathConcept: We can subtract multiples of 10 from two-digit numbers.
pages.mathTip: Subtract tens just like subtracting ones, but in the tens place.

pages.sentence: I have 60 rice balls. That is 6 packs of 10. I give away 20 rice balls. That is 2 packs. I take away 2 tens. 6 tens minus 2 tens equals 4 tens. 60 minus 20 equals 40.
pages.mathConcept: To subtract multiples of 10, subtract the tens.
pages.mathTip: 6 tens - 2 tens = 4 tens. So 60 - 20 = 40.

pages.question: How many do I have left?
pages.mathContext: I have 60 rice balls. I sell 20 rice balls.
pages.mathHint: Think tens. 6 tens - 2 tens = 4 tens. So 60 - 20 = 40.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 60 - 20 = 40. You subtracted tens!

pages.sentence: Now I try a harder one. I have 84 rice balls. I give away 30. I look at the tens. 8 tens minus 3 tens equals 5 tens. The ones stay 4. 84 minus 30 equals 54.
pages.mathConcept: When subtracting tens, the ones digit stays the same.
pages.mathTip: Subtract only the tens. Keep the ones the same.

pages.question: How many left?
pages.mathContext: I count 84 rice balls. I give 30 to my friends.
pages.mathHint: Tens: 8 - 3 = 5. Ones stay 4. Answer: 54.
pages.successMessage: Great! 84 - 30 = 54. The ones stayed the same!

pages.menuStory: The rice ball shop has different flavors. I pick my favorite filling.

pages.sentence: I can subtract tens in my head. I think about the tens place. 75 minus 40? 7 tens minus 4 tens equals 3 tens. The ones stay 5. So 75 minus 40 equals 35!
pages.mathConcept: Use mental math to subtract multiples of 10.
pages.mathTip: Focus on the tens digit. The ones do not change.

pages.question: How many rice balls are not packed?
pages.mathContext: I start with 75 rice balls. I pack 40 into boxes.
pages.mathHint: Tens: 7 - 4 = 3. Ones stay 5. Answer: 35.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 75 - 40 = 35!

pages.sentence: I practice more. 92 minus 50. Tens: 9 minus 5 equals 4 tens. Ones: 2 stays 2. 92 minus 50 equals 42. I am getting fast at this!
pages.mathConcept: Practice makes subtracting tens automatic.
pages.mathTip: The more you practice, the easier it gets!

pages.question: How many are left?
pages.mathContext: The shop has 92 rice balls. They sell 50 rice balls.
pages.mathHint: Tens: 9 - 5 = 4. Ones stay 2. Answer: 42.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 92 - 50 = 42. Great work!

pages.sentence: Subtracting tens is a useful skill. I can solve problems quickly. I just think about tens and ones separately. Easy!
pages.mathConcept: Understanding place value makes subtraction easier.
pages.mathTip: Always think: what are the tens doing? What are the ones doing?

pages.question: How many do I keep?
pages.mathContext: I have 67 rice balls. I give 20 to the lunch program.
pages.mathHint: Tens: 6 - 2 = 4. Ones stay 7. Answer: 47.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! 67 - 20 = 47. You are a subtraction star!

pages.sentence: I am at the noodle house. The chef makes noodles. Some noodles are long. Some noodles are short.
pages.mathConcept: Comparing lengths
pages.mathTip: Look at how long each object is.

pages.question: Which noodle is longer?
pages.mathContext: I see two noodles. One is long. One is short.
pages.mathHint: Look at both noodles. Find the one that goes farther.
pages.successMessage: Yes! You found the longer noodle.

pages.sentence: I see breadsticks too. I put them next to each other. Now I can compare them.
pages.mathConcept: Lining up to compare
pages.mathTip: Line up objects at one end to compare lengths.

pages.question: Which breadstick is shorter?
pages.mathContext: Two breadsticks are lined up at the left. I can see which is shorter.
pages.mathHint: Look for the one that ends first. That one is shorter.
pages.successMessage: Great! You found the shorter breadstick.

pages.sentence: The train has three cars. Car A is long. Car B is longer. Car C is the longest.
pages.mathConcept: Ordering by length
pages.mathTip: You can put objects in order from shortest to longest.

pages.menuStory: The chef asks what I want. I look at the menu. I choose my favorite.

pages.question: Which train car is the longest?
pages.mathContext: I see three train cars. They have different lengths.
pages.mathHint: Look at all three. Find the one that goes the farthest.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The blue car is the longest.

pages.question: Which chopstick is the shortest?
pages.mathContext: Three chopsticks are on the table. I need to find the shortest one.
pages.mathHint: Look for the chopstick that is the smallest. It ends first.
pages.successMessage: Nice work! Chopstick 2 is the shortest.

pages.sentence: I can put noodles in order. First the shortest. Then longer. Last the longest.
pages.mathConcept: Ordering from shortest to longest
pages.mathTip: Start with the smallest. End with the biggest.

pages.question: Put the noodles in order from shortest to longest. Which comes first?
pages.mathContext: I have noodle A, noodle B, and noodle C. I need to order them.
pages.mathHint: Find the shortest noodle. That one comes first.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Noodle B is shortest, so it comes first.

pages.question: Spoon A is 6 units long. Spoon B is 4 units long. Which spoon is longer?
pages.mathContext: Two spoons have different lengths. I compare them.
pages.mathHint: Longer means bigger. Which number is bigger, 6 or 4?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 6 is more than 4, so Spoon A is longer.

pages.sentence: I am at the cookie shop. I see cookies of the same size. I can use cookies to measure things.
pages.mathConcept: Using same-size units to measure
pages.mathTip: To measure, use objects that are all the same size.

pages.question: How many cookies long is the tray?
pages.mathContext: I line up cookies along the tray. I count them to measure.
pages.mathHint: Count the cookies. How many cookies fit?
pages.successMessage: Yes! The tray is 4 cookies long.

pages.sentence: I need to line up the cookies carefully. No gaps between them. No overlaps. Then I count.
pages.mathConcept: Measuring without gaps or overlaps
pages.mathTip: Put units side by side with no spaces and no overlaps.

pages.question: Which way of measuring is correct?
pages.mathContext: I see three ways to measure. Only one has no gaps and no overlaps.
pages.mathHint: Look for units that touch but do not overlap. No spaces between them.
pages.successMessage: Great! Units should touch with no gaps or overlaps.

pages.sentence: I can use crackers to measure too. The bench is 6 crackers long. I counted 6 crackers.
pages.mathConcept: Measuring with different units
pages.mathTip: You can measure with any same-size objects.

pages.menuStory: The baker shows me the cookie tray. They all look delicious. I choose one.

pages.question: How many crackers long is the box?
pages.mathContext: A box is measured with crackers. I count the crackers.
pages.mathHint: Count all the crackers from one end to the other.
pages.successMessage: Correct! The box is 5 crackers long.

pages.question: The counter is 7 cookies long. How many cookies did I use?
pages.mathContext: I measured the counter with cookies. It is 7 cookies long.
pages.mathHint: If it is 7 cookies long, I used 7 cookies.
pages.successMessage: Yes! You need 7 cookies to measure 7 cookies long.

pages.sentence: The shelf is 9 napkins wide. I used napkins to measure the shelf width.
pages.mathConcept: Measuring different dimensions
pages.mathTip: You can measure length, width, or height with units.

pages.question: Plate A is 3 spoons long. Plate B is 5 spoons long. Which plate is longer?
pages.mathContext: Two plates are measured with spoons. I compare the measurements.
pages.mathHint: Which number is bigger, 3 or 5? That plate is longer.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 5 is more than 3, so Plate B is longer.

pages.question: The baker measures the rolling pin. It is 8 cookies long. How many cookies did she use?
pages.mathContext: The rolling pin is measured using cookies as units.
pages.mathHint: The measurement is 8 cookies. So she used 8 cookies.
pages.successMessage: Yes! If it is 8 cookies long, she used 8 cookies.

previewConcepts.concept: Tell time to the half hour

pages.sentence: I am at the train station. I look at the big clock. The clock tells me what time it is.
pages.mathConcept: Reading clocks to tell time
pages.mathTip: Clocks have an hour hand and a minute hand.

pages.question: What time is it?
pages.mathContext: The clock shows the hour hand on 2. The minute hand is on 12.
pages.mathHint: When the minute hand points to 12, we say o'clock. Look at the hour hand.
pages.successMessage: Yes! It is 2 o'clock.

pages.sentence: When the minute hand points to 12, we say o'clock. The hour hand shows which hour.
pages.mathConcept: Understanding o'clock
pages.mathTip: Minute hand on 12 means o'clock. Hour hand tells the hour.

pages.question: The train leaves at 7 o'clock. Which clock shows 7 o'clock?
pages.mathContext: I need to find the clock that shows 7 o'clock.
pages.mathHint: Look for the hour hand on 7 and the minute hand on 12.
pages.successMessage: Correct! That clock shows 7 o'clock.

pages.sentence: Sometimes the minute hand points to 6. That means half past the hour. It is 30 minutes past.
pages.mathConcept: Understanding half past
pages.mathTip: When the minute hand points to 6, say half past.

pages.prompt: Pick your snack for the train ride!
pages.menuStory: The snack cart arrives. I can pick something to eat on the train.

pages.question: What time is it?
pages.mathContext: The hour hand is between 4 and 5. The minute hand points to 6.
pages.mathHint: The minute hand on 6 means half past. The hour hand shows 4.
pages.successMessage: Yes! It is half past 4.

pages.sentence: Digital clocks show time with numbers. 3 colon 00 means 3 o'clock. 3 colon 30 means half past 3.
pages.mathConcept: Reading digital time
pages.mathTip: Numbers after the colon show minutes. 00 is o'clock. 30 is half past.

pages.question: The digital clock shows 6 colon 00. What time is it?
pages.mathContext: I see a digital clock. It says 6 colon 00.
pages.mathHint: The number before the colon is the hour. 00 means o'clock.
pages.successMessage: Great! 6 colon 00 is 6 o'clock.

pages.question: What time does this digital clock show?
pages.mathContext: The digital clock displays 8 colon 30.
pages.mathHint: 30 means half past. The hour is 8.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 8 colon 30 is half past 8.

pages.question: The analog clock shows half past 5. What will the digital clock say?
pages.mathContext: I need to match analog time to digital time.
pages.mathHint: Half past 5 means 5 colon 30.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Half past 5 is 5 colon 30.

pages.question: The train arrives at 9 o'clock. What time does it arrive?
pages.mathContext: The schedule says the train comes at 9 o'clock.
pages.mathHint: 9 o'clock means the hour hand is on 9 and the minute hand is on 12.
pages.successMessage: Correct! The train arrives at 9 o'clock.

pages.sentence: I am doing a snack survey. I ask friends what snack they like best. I write down their answers.
pages.mathConcept: Collecting data
pages.mathTip: Data is information we collect and organize.

pages.question: I collected snack data. Apple, banana, apple, orange. How many chose apple?
pages.mathContext: The list shows: apple, banana, apple, orange. I need to count apples.
pages.mathHint: Count how many times apple appears in the list.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Apple appears 2 times.

pages.sentence: I can sort the data into groups. All the apples go together. All the bananas go together. All the oranges go together.
pages.mathConcept: Organizing data into categories
pages.mathTip: Put things that are the same into groups.

pages.question: I sorted snacks. 3 apples, 2 bananas, 1 orange. How many categories did I make?
pages.mathContext: The snacks are sorted into apple group, banana group, and orange group.
pages.mathHint: Count the different groups. Apple is one group. Banana is another. Orange is another.
pages.successMessage: Correct! There are 3 categories: apple, banana, orange.

pages.sentence: I make a picture graph. Each picture stands for one person. I can see the data easily now.
pages.mathConcept: Representing data with a graph
pages.mathTip: A picture graph shows data with pictures. Each picture is one.

pages.menuStory: I am taking a survey. What is your favorite snack? Your vote will be added to the graph.

pages.question: Look at the graph. How many people chose banana?
pages.mathContext: The picture graph shows banana has 2 banana pictures.
pages.mathHint: Count the banana pictures. Each picture is one person.
pages.successMessage: Yes! There are 2 banana pictures, so 2 people chose banana.

pages.sentence: I can use tally marks too. Each line is one. When I get to 5, I draw a line across.
pages.mathConcept: Using tally marks to organize data
pages.mathTip: Tally marks are a way to keep count. 5 makes a group.

pages.question: The tally marks show 3 lines for apple. How many people chose apple?
pages.mathContext: Tally marks for apple: 3 lines. Each line is one person.
pages.mathHint: Count the tally marks. Each mark is one person.
pages.successMessage: Correct! 3 tally marks means 3 people.

pages.question: I have data: cookie, cracker, cookie, cookie, cracker. What are the categories?
pages.mathContext: The data has cookies and crackers. I need to identify the groups.
pages.mathHint: Look at what types appear. Cookie is one type. Cracker is another type.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The two categories are cookie and cracker.

pages.question: The graph shows 4 votes for rice, 3 votes for noodles, and 2 votes for bread. How many people voted in all?
pages.mathContext: I need to add all the votes together.
pages.mathHint: Add all the groups together. 4 plus 3 plus 2.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 4 plus 3 plus 2 equals 9 people voted.

pages.question: I asked 6 friends. 2 like tea, 3 like juice, 1 likes milk. How should I organize this data?
pages.mathContext: I have drink preferences from 6 friends. I need to organize them.
pages.mathHint: Make groups for each drink type: tea, juice, and milk.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Organize by categories: tea, juice, and milk.

pages.sentence: I am at the food court. I see a graph of favorite foods. The graph shows data. I can answer questions by reading the graph.
pages.mathConcept: Interpreting data from graphs
pages.mathTip: Look at the graph carefully. Count to find answers.

pages.question: How many people chose sushi?
pages.mathContext: The graph shows sushi has 4 pictures. Each picture is one person.
pages.mathHint: Count the sushi pictures in the graph.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 4 people chose sushi.

pages.sentence: I can compare the data. Sushi has the most. Rice has the least. Ramen is in the middle.
pages.mathConcept: Comparing data: most and least
pages.mathTip: Most means the biggest amount. Least means the smallest amount.

pages.question: Which food is most popular?
pages.mathContext: I look at the graph. Most popular means it has the most votes.
pages.mathHint: Find the category with the most pictures. That is most popular.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Sushi has the most, so it is most popular.

pages.question: Which food has the least votes?
pages.mathContext: I need to find which food has the smallest number.
pages.mathHint: Look for the category with the fewest pictures.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Rice has the least with only 2 votes.

pages.menuStory: I am at the food court. So many good choices. I pick what I want to eat.

pages.sentence: I can find the difference. Sushi has 4. Rice has 2. Sushi has 2 more than rice.
pages.mathConcept: Finding how many more in data
pages.mathTip: Subtract to find how many more. The bigger number minus the smaller number.

pages.question: Sushi has 4 votes. Ramen has 3 votes. How many more people chose sushi than ramen?
pages.mathContext: I compare sushi and ramen. I need to find the difference.
pages.mathHint: Subtract. 4 minus 3 equals how many more.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 4 minus 3 equals 1. Sushi has 1 more vote.

pages.question: Rice has 2 votes. Ramen has 3 votes. How many fewer people chose rice than ramen?
pages.mathContext: I compare rice and ramen. Fewer means less.
pages.mathHint: Subtract the smaller from the bigger. 3 minus 2.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 3 minus 2 equals 1. Rice has 1 fewer vote.

pages.sentence: A new graph shows drinks. Tea has 5 votes. Juice has 3 votes. Milk has 4 votes.
pages.mathConcept: Reading and interpreting new data
pages.mathTip: Each new graph tells a different story. Read it carefully.

pages.question: Look at the drinks graph. Which drink is most popular?
pages.mathContext: Tea has 5, juice has 3, milk has 4. I need to find which is most.
pages.mathHint: Compare all three numbers. Which is biggest? 5, 3, or 4?
pages.successMessage: Correct! Tea has 5 votes, which is the most.

pages.question: How many people voted for drinks in total?
pages.mathContext: Tea has 5, juice has 3, milk has 4. I add them all.
pages.mathHint: Add all three categories. 5 plus 3 plus 4.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 5 plus 3 plus 4 equals 12 people total.

pages.question: The graph shows 6 people like dumplings and 4 people like spring rolls. How many more people like dumplings?
pages.mathContext: I need to compare dumplings and spring rolls to find the difference.
pages.mathHint: Subtract to find how many more. 6 minus 4.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 6 minus 4 equals 2. Dumplings has 2 more votes.

previewConcepts.example: Make shapes with sides and corners

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Shape Station. I see windows on the walls. The windows have different shapes. I look at the sides and corners.
pages.mathConcept: Shapes have sides and corners we can count
pages.mathTip: Look carefully at the sides. Then count the corners.

pages.question: What parts of shapes do we look at?
pages.mathContext: I see windows on the walls. The windows have different shapes. I look at the sides and corners.
pages.mathHint: Read the last sentence. What two things do I look at?
pages.successMessage: Yes! We look at sides and corners.

pages.sentence: I see a square window. I count the sides. There are 4 sides. I count the corners. There are 4 corners. A square has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathConcept: A square has 4 equal sides and 4 corners
pages.mathTip: Touch each side as you count. Then touch each corner.

pages.question: How many sides does a square have?
pages.mathContext: I see a square window. A square has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count the sides of the square. Touch each one.
pages.successMessage: Great! A square has 4 sides.

pages.sentence: I see a triangle sign on the wall. I count the sides. There are 3 sides. I count the corners. There are 3 corners. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners.
pages.mathConcept: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners
pages.mathTip: Count each side. Then count each corner.

pages.question: How many corners does a triangle have?
pages.mathContext: I see a triangle sign on the wall. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count the corners of the triangle. Point to each one.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A triangle has 3 corners.

pages.menuStory: The snack cart has treats. Each snack is a different shape. What will you choose?

pages.sentence: I see a rectangle tile on the floor. I count the sides. There are 4 sides. I count the corners. There are 4 corners. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathConcept: A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners
pages.mathTip: A rectangle is like a square but longer on two sides.

pages.question: Which shape has 3 sides?
pages.mathContext: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners. A square has 4 sides and 4 corners. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Think about each shape. Which one has 3 sides?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A triangle has 3 sides.

pages.question: I want to build a shape with 4 corners. Which shape should I build?
pages.mathContext: A triangle has 3 corners. A square has 4 corners. A rectangle has 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count how many corners each shape has. Which ones have 4?
pages.successMessage: Great! A square has 4 corners.

pages.question: How many sides does a rectangle have?
pages.mathContext: I see a rectangle tile on the floor. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count the sides of the rectangle. Go around all the edges.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A rectangle has 4 sides.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Food Court. I see many foods. Each food has a shape. I can make 2D shapes. 2D shapes are flat.
pages.mathConcept: 2D shapes are flat shapes like circles, squares, and triangles
pages.mathTip: 2D means flat. You can draw 2D shapes on paper.

pages.question: What does 2D mean?
pages.mathContext: I can make 2D shapes. 2D shapes are flat.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentence. What word describes 2D shapes?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 2D shapes are flat.

pages.sentence: I see a pizza. The pizza is a circle. A circle is round. It has no sides and no corners. The pizza is a flat circle.
pages.mathConcept: A circle is round with no sides and no corners
pages.mathTip: A circle is round all the way around. No sides. No corners.

pages.question: What shape is the pizza?
pages.mathContext: I see a pizza. The pizza is a circle.
pages.mathHint: Read about the pizza. What shape is it?
pages.successMessage: Great! The pizza is a circle.

pages.sentence: I see a sandwich. The sandwich is a rectangle. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners. Two sides are long. Two sides are short.
pages.mathConcept: A rectangle has 4 sides (2 long, 2 short) and 4 corners
pages.mathTip: In a rectangle, opposite sides are the same length.

pages.question: What shape is the sandwich?
pages.mathContext: I see a sandwich. The sandwich is a rectangle.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentences. Find the shape of the sandwich.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The sandwich is a rectangle.

pages.sentence: I see a rice ball. The rice ball is a triangle. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners. All the sides make a triangle shape.
pages.mathConcept: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners
pages.mathTip: Count the sides of a triangle. Then count the corners.

pages.menuStory: The food court has many foods. Each one is a different shape. What will you eat?

pages.question: How many sides does the rice ball have?
pages.mathContext: I see a rice ball. The rice ball is a triangle. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners.
pages.mathHint: A triangle has how many sides? Count them.
pages.successMessage: Nice! A triangle has 3 sides.

pages.sentence: I see a cheese slice. The cheese slice is a trapezoid. A trapezoid has 4 sides and 4 corners. The sides are different lengths.
pages.mathConcept: A trapezoid has 4 sides of different lengths
pages.mathTip: A trapezoid has 4 sides, but they are not all the same length.

pages.question: Which food is a circle?
pages.mathContext: The pizza is a circle. The sandwich is a rectangle. The rice ball is a triangle.
pages.mathHint: Think about which food is round. Circles are round.
pages.successMessage: Great! The pizza is a circle.

pages.question: I want to make a square. How many sides do I need?
pages.mathContext: A square has 4 sides and 4 corners. All sides are the same length.
pages.mathHint: Think about a square. Count the sides.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A square has 4 sides.

pages.question: Which shape has no corners?
pages.mathContext: A circle is round. It has no sides and no corners. A square has 4 corners. A triangle has 3 corners.
pages.mathHint: Think about each shape. Which one has no corners at all?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A circle has no corners.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Drink Station. I see many drinks. The drinks come in 3D shapes. 3D shapes are solid. They are not flat. I can put shapes together to make a new shape.
pages.mathConcept: 3D shapes are solid shapes that are not flat
pages.mathTip: 3D means solid. You can hold 3D shapes in your hand.

pages.question: What does 3D mean?
pages.mathContext: The drinks come in 3D shapes. 3D shapes are solid. They are not flat.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentence. What word describes 3D shapes?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 3D shapes are solid.

pages.sentence: I see a juice box. The juice box is a rectangular prism. It has 6 flat faces. It has 12 edges. It looks like a box.
pages.mathConcept: A rectangular prism has 6 faces and 12 edges
pages.mathTip: A rectangular prism is like a box. Count the flat sides.

pages.question: What shape is the juice box?
pages.mathContext: I see a juice box. The juice box is a rectangular prism.
pages.mathHint: Read about the juice box. What is its shape?
pages.successMessage: Great! The juice box is a rectangular prism.

pages.sentence: I see a soda can. The soda can is a cylinder. It has 2 flat faces on the top and bottom. It has 1 curved edge. It can roll.
pages.mathConcept: A cylinder has 2 flat circular faces and 1 curved surface
pages.mathTip: A cylinder can roll. It has circles on the ends.

pages.question: What shape is the soda can?
pages.mathContext: I see a soda can. The soda can is a cylinder.
pages.mathHint: Read about the soda can. Find its shape.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The soda can is a cylinder.

pages.menuStory: The drink station has many choices. Each drink has a different shape. What will you choose?

pages.sentence: I see an ice cream cone. The ice cream cone is a cone. It has 1 flat face on the bottom. It has 1 point at the top. It can roll and slide.
pages.mathConcept: A cone has 1 flat circular face and 1 point
pages.mathTip: A cone has a point. It has a circle at the bottom.

pages.question: What shape is the ice cream cone?
pages.mathContext: I see an ice cream cone. The ice cream cone is a cone.
pages.mathHint: Read about the ice cream. What shape is it?
pages.successMessage: Nice! The ice cream cone is a cone.

pages.sentence: I see ice cubes in my drink. Each ice cube is a cube. A cube has 6 square faces. All the faces are the same size.
pages.mathConcept: A cube has 6 equal square faces
pages.mathTip: A cube is like a box. All sides are squares. All sides are equal.

pages.question: What two shapes can you put together to make an ice cream cone on a cup?
pages.mathContext: A cone can sit on top of a cylinder cup. Together they make a new shape.
pages.mathHint: Ice cream cone = cone. Cup = cylinder.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Cone + cylinder makes a new shape.

pages.question: A juice box with a straw looks like what two shapes together?
pages.mathContext: A juice box is a rectangular prism. A straw is like a cylinder.
pages.mathHint: Match each object to a 3D shape.
pages.successMessage: Great! Juice box (rectangular prism) + straw (cylinder).

pages.question: Which two shapes could you put together to make a drink with ice cubes?
pages.mathContext: A cup is like a cylinder. Ice cubes are cubes. Together they make a new shape.
pages.mathHint: Cup = cylinder. Ice cubes = cubes.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Cubes in a cylinder cup make a new shape.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Tile Workshop. I see many tiles. The tiles are different shapes. I can put shapes together to make new shapes.
pages.mathConcept: We can combine shapes to create new, bigger shapes
pages.mathTip: When you put shapes together, you can make a new shape.

pages.question: What can I do with shapes?
pages.mathContext: I see many tiles. The tiles are different shapes. I can put shapes together to make new shapes.
pages.mathHint: Read the last sentence. What can I do?
pages.successMessage: Yes! You can put shapes together.

pages.sentence: I take two triangles. I put them together. The two triangles make a square. I made a new shape from two shapes.
pages.mathConcept: Two triangles can combine to make a square
pages.mathTip: When you put two right triangles together, they can make a square.

pages.question: What shape do two triangles make?
pages.mathContext: I take two triangles. I put them together. The two triangles make a square.
pages.mathHint: Read about the two triangles. What do they make?
pages.successMessage: Great! Two triangles make a square.

pages.sentence: I take two squares. I put them side by side. The two squares make a rectangle. The rectangle is longer than one square.
pages.mathConcept: Two squares side by side make a rectangle
pages.mathTip: When you put squares next to each other, you make a rectangle.

pages.question: What do two squares make when you put them side by side?
pages.mathContext: I take two squares. I put them side by side. The two squares make a rectangle.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentence. What shape do two squares make?
pages.successMessage: Yes! Two squares make a rectangle.

pages.menuStory: The workshop has many tile projects. Each one uses different shapes. What will you build?

pages.sentence: I make a big triangle. I use three small triangles. I put them together carefully. Now I have one big triangle made from three small triangles.
pages.mathConcept: Smaller shapes can combine to make larger shapes of the same type
pages.mathTip: You can use small shapes to build bigger shapes.

pages.question: How many small triangles did I use?
pages.mathContext: I make a big triangle. I use three small triangles. Now I have one big triangle made from three small triangles.
pages.mathHint: Count how many small triangles I used.
pages.successMessage: Nice! You used 3 small triangles.

pages.question: I want to make a rectangle. Which shapes can I use?
pages.mathContext: Two squares make a rectangle. Two triangles can make a square. Shapes can combine to make new shapes.
pages.mathHint: Think about what shapes combine to make a rectangle.
pages.successMessage: Great! Two squares make a rectangle.

pages.question: What new shape can two triangles make?
pages.mathContext: I take two triangles. I put them together. The two triangles make a square.
pages.mathHint: Remember what happened when we put two triangles together.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Two triangles can make a square.

pages.question: I have 4 small squares. I put them in a 2 by 2 pattern. What shape do I make?
pages.mathContext: Small squares can combine to make bigger shapes. When you put 4 squares in a square pattern, you make a bigger square.
pages.mathHint: Think about 4 squares in a square pattern. What big shape do they make?
pages.successMessage: Nice! 4 small squares make a big square.

previewConcepts.example: Cut a pizza into 2 equal parts
Cut a pizza into 4 equal parts
All pieces are the same size

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Pizza Party. I see pizzas and sandwiches. I need to share the food fairly. I will cut the food into equal parts.
pages.mathConcept: Fair sharing means cutting into equal parts
pages.mathTip: Equal parts means all the pieces are the same size.

pages.question: What does equal parts mean?
pages.mathContext: I need to share the food fairly. I will cut the food into equal parts.
pages.mathHint: Read about equal parts. What does it mean?
pages.successMessage: Yes! Equal parts are the same size.

pages.sentence: I cut a pizza into 2 equal parts. Each part is called a half. There are 2 halves. The 2 halves make 1 whole pizza.
pages.mathConcept: A half is 1 of 2 equal parts
pages.mathTip: When you cut something into 2 equal parts, each part is a half.

pages.question: How many halves are in 1 whole pizza?
pages.mathContext: I cut a pizza into 2 equal parts. There are 2 halves. The 2 halves make 1 whole pizza.
pages.mathHint: Count the halves. How many equal parts?
pages.successMessage: Great! There are 2 halves in 1 whole.

pages.sentence: I cut a sandwich into 4 equal parts. Each part is called a fourth. Each part is also called a quarter. There are 4 fourths. The 4 fourths make 1 whole sandwich.
pages.mathConcept: A fourth or quarter is 1 of 4 equal parts
pages.mathTip: When you cut into 4 equal parts, each part is a fourth or a quarter.

pages.question: How many fourths are in 1 whole sandwich?
pages.mathContext: I cut a sandwich into 4 equal parts. There are 4 fourths. The 4 fourths make 1 whole sandwich.
pages.mathHint: Count the fourths. How many equal parts?
pages.successMessage: Yes! There are 4 fourths in 1 whole.

pages.menuStory: The party has different foods to share. Each one can be cut into equal parts. What will you share?

pages.question: What is another name for a fourth?
pages.mathContext: Each part is called a fourth. Each part is also called a quarter.
pages.mathHint: Read about fourths. What is another name?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A fourth is also called a quarter.

pages.sentence: I need to share a cookie with my friend. I cut it into 2 equal parts. We each get 1 half. This is a fair share.
pages.mathConcept: Sharing fairly means each person gets an equal part
pages.mathTip: When we share fairly, everyone gets the same amount.

pages.question: I want to share a pizza with 3 friends. How many equal parts do I need?
pages.mathContext: I need to share fairly. I cut into equal parts. Each person gets 1 equal part.
pages.mathHint: Count how many people. You and 3 friends is 4 people total.
pages.successMessage: Great! 4 people need 4 equal parts.

pages.question: Which cut makes halves?
pages.mathContext: A half is 1 of 2 equal parts. When I cut into 2 equal parts, I make halves.
pages.mathHint: Think about halves. How many parts are there?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 2 equal parts make halves.

pages.question: Which cut makes fourths?
pages.mathContext: A fourth is 1 of 4 equal parts. When I cut into 4 equal parts, I make fourths.
pages.mathHint: Think about fourths. How many parts are there?
pages.successMessage: Nice! 4 equal parts make fourths.

pages.question: Are these parts equal?
pages.mathContext: I see a pizza cut into 2 parts. One part is big. One part is small. These parts are not equal.
pages.mathHint: Look at the two parts. Are they the same size?
pages.successMessage: Right! The parts are not equal.

pages.sentence: Let us review what we learned. We will do some quick math!
pages.mathConcept: Review introduction
pages.mathTip: Take your time and think.

pages.prompt: Pick a snack for your review break!
pages.menuStory: Good work! Pick a treat.

pages.question: How many apples do I have now?
pages.mathContext: I have 4 apples. I get 5 more.
pages.mathHint: Count on from the bigger number.

pages.question: I have 13 grapes. I eat 6. How many grapes are left?
pages.mathContext: Start with 13. Take away 6.
pages.mathHint: Count back 6 or use a ten-frame idea.

pages.question: In the number 37, what does the 3 mean?
pages.mathContext: 37 has tens and ones.
pages.mathHint: The first digit tells how many tens.
pages.successMessage: Correct! 37 is 3 tens and 7 ones.

pages.question: Which shows 14?
pages.mathContext: 14 is a teen number.
pages.mathHint: Teen numbers are 1 ten and some ones.
pages.successMessage: Great! 14 = 1 ten and 4 ones.

pages.question: Which shape has 3 sides?
pages.mathContext: Look at the shape names.
pages.mathHint: A triangle has 3 sides.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A triangle has 3 sides.

pages.sentence: Time for more review! We will practice harder problems.
pages.mathConcept: Review introduction
pages.mathTip: You can do it! Think step by step.

pages.menuStory: Great job reviewing! Pick a sticker.

pages.question: What number is missing? ____ + 4 = 10
pages.mathContext: I need 10 stickers. I have 4. How many more do I need?
pages.mathHint: Think: what plus 4 equals 10?

pages.question: I had 12 stickers. Now I have 9. How many did I give away? 12 ‚àí ____ = 9
pages.mathContext: This is a missing number problem.
pages.mathHint: What number makes 12 ‚àí ____ equal 9?

pages.question: What is 47 + 6?
pages.mathContext: Add tens and ones.
pages.mathHint: Add ones: 7 + 6 = 13. Regroup 1 ten. Tens: 4 + 1 = 5. Answer: 53.

pages.question: A cookie is cut into 4 equal parts. One part is called a ____.
pages.mathContext: 4 equal parts means fourths.
pages.mathHint: Fourth means 1 out of 4 equal parts.
pages.successMessage: Yes! One out of 4 equal parts is a fourth (a quarter).

pages.question: If you cut a sandwich into more equal parts, each part is ____.
pages.mathContext: More equal parts means smaller shares.
pages.mathHint: More shares makes each share smaller.
pages.successMessage: Correct! More equal parts makes smaller parts.
